title: Super fees drop but are still too high
text:
Superannuation fees have dropped for the first time since 2014 but the average member is still paying too much, according to new analysis by Rainmaker Information.

Total administration and investment fees across the industry were estimated at $31.8 billion in 2018-19, down from $33.2 billion in the previous year.

But fees are still rising faster than inflation and the average member pays the equivalent of more than 1 per cent of their account balance in fees, which experts say is too much.

Rainmaker's analysis says costs are coming down because of economies of scale. "As total superannuation assets continue to grow towards $3 trillion, the fees members pay for the administration and investment of their balances have for the first time in six years come down," it says.

Retail funds, which have always been more expensive than industry funds, have been slashing their fees and some of the cheapest offerings are in this segment, the Rainmaker report says.

The uptake of index investing, albeit in a limited way, is also influencing investment costs, it also says.
description: Fees are still rising faster than inflation and the average member pays the equivalent of more than 1 per cent of their account balance in fees, which experts say is too much. And the fees charged by industry funds are now rising.
